chunk:
C0) require dramatically fewer tokens per query (9x-43x).
Community summaries vs. source texts. When comparing community summaries to source texts
using Graph RAG, community summaries generally provided a small but consistent improvement
in answer comprehensiveness and diversity, except for root-level summaries. Intermediate-level
summaries in the Podcast dataset and low-level community summaries in the News dataset achieved
comprehensiveness win rates of 57% and 64%, respectively. Diversity win rates were 57% for
Podcast intermediate-level summaries and 60% for News low-level community summaries. Table 3
also illustrates the scalability advantages of Graph RAG compared to source text summarization: for
low-level community summaries ( C3), Graph RAG required 26-33% fewer context tokens, while
for root-level community summaries ( C0), it required over 97% fewer tokens. For a modest drop in
performance compared with other global methods, root-level Graph RAG offers a highly efficient
method for the iterative question answering that characterizes sensemaking activity, while retaining
advantages in comprehensiveness (72% win rate) and diversity (62% win rate) over na ¨ıve RAG.
Empowerment . Empowerment comparisons showed mixed results for both global approaches versus
na¨ıve RAG ( SS) and Graph RAG approaches versus source text summarization ( TS). Ad-hoc LLM
use to analyze LLM reasoning for this measure indicated that the ability to provide specific exam-
ples, quotes, and citations was judged to be key to helping users reach an informed understanding.
Tuning element extraction prompts may help to retain more of these details in the Graph RAG index.
4 Related Work
4.1 RAG Approaches and Systems
When using LLMs, RAG involves first retrieving relevant information from external data sources,
then adding this information to the context window of the LLM along with the original query (Ram
et al., 2023). Na ¨ıve RAG approaches (Gao et al., 2023) do this by converting documents to text,
splitting text into chunks, and embedding these chunks into a vector space in which similar positions
represent similar semantics. Queries are then embedded into the same vector space, with the text
chunks of the nearest kvectors used as context. More advanced variations exist, but all solve the
problem of what to do when an external dataset of interest exceeds the LLM

entities.name: COMMUNITY SUMMARIES
entities.description: Community summaries are condensed versions of source texts, often created by a group or community, and are used to improve answer comprehensiveness and diversity

entities.name: SOURCE TEXTS
entities.description: Source texts are the original documents from which community summaries are derived

entities.name: GRAPH RAG
entities.description: Graph RAG is a method used to compare community summaries to source texts, showing improvements in comprehensiveness and diversity while requiring fewer tokens

entities.name: PODCAST DATASET
entities.description: The Podcast dataset is a collection of podcast transcripts used to evaluate the comprehensiveness and diversity of intermediate-level community summaries

entities.name: NEWS DATASET
entities.description: The News dataset is a collection of news articles used to evaluate the comprehensiveness and diversity of low-level community summaries

entities.name: ROOT-LEVEL SUMMARIES
entities.description: Root-level summaries are the highest-level summaries in a hierarchical summarization system, showing significant token reduction but a modest drop in performance

entities.name: INTERMEDIATE-LEVEL SUMMARIES
entities.description: Intermediate-level summaries are mid-tier summaries in a hierarchical summarization system, showing improvements in comprehensiveness and diversity

entities.name: LOW-LEVEL COMMUNITY SUMMARIES
entities.description: Low-level community summaries are the most detailed summaries in a hierarchical summarization system, showing improvements in comprehensiveness and diversity

entities.name: NAÏVE RAG
entities.description: Naïve RAG is a basic method for retrieving and adding relevant information to the context window of an LLM, often used as a baseline for comparison

entities.name: EMPOWERMENT
entities.description: Empowerment is a measure used to compare the effectiveness of different summarization and retrieval methods in helping users reach an informed understanding

entities.name: LLM
entities.description: LLM stands for Large Language Model, a type of AI used for natural language processing tasks

entities.name: RAG APPROACHES
entities.description: RAG approaches involve retrieving relevant information from external data sources and adding it to the context window of an LLM

entities.name: RAM ET AL., 2023
entities.description: A study by Ram et al. in 2023 that discusses RAG approaches and their applications

entities.name: SENSEMAKING ACTIVITY
entities.description: Sensemaking activity involves iterative question answering to help users understand complex information

entities.description: Tuning element extraction prompts is a method to retain more details in the Graph RAG index

chunk:
these chunks into a vector space in which similar positions
represent similar semantics. Queries are then embedded into the same vector space, with the text
chunks of the nearest kvectors used as context. More advanced variations exist, but all solve the
problem of what to do when an external dataset of interest exceeds the LLM’s context window.
Advanced RAG systems include pre-retrieval, retrieval, post-retrieval strategies designed to over-
come the drawbacks of Na ¨ıve RAG, while Modular RAG systems include patterns for iterative and
dynamic cycles of interleaved retrieval and generation (Gao et al., 2023). Our implementation of
Graph RAG incorporates multiple concepts related to other systems. For example, our community
summaries are a kind of self-memory (Selfmem, Cheng et al., 2024) for generation-augmented re-
trieval (GAR, Mao et al., 2020) that facilitates future generation cycles, while our parallel generation
of community answers from these summaries is a kind of iterative (Iter-RetGen, Shao et al., 2023)
or federated (FeB4RAG, Wang et al., 2024) retrieval-generation strategy. Other systems have also
combined these concepts for multi-document summarization (CAiRE-COVID, Su et al., 2020) and
multi-hop question answering (ITRG, Feng et al., 2023; IR-CoT, Trivedi et al., 2022; DSP, Khattab
et al., 2022). Our use of a hierarchical index and summarization also bears resemblance to further
approaches, such as generating a hierarchical index of text chunks by clustering the vectors of text
embeddings (RAPTOR, Sarthi et al., 2024) or generating a “tree of clarifications” to answer mul-
tiple interpretations of ambiguous questions (Kim et al., 2023). However, none of these iterative or
hierarchical approaches use the kind of self-generated graph index that enables Graph RAG.
104.2 Graphs and LLMs
Use of graphs in connection with LLMs and RAG is a developing research area, with multiple
directions already established. These include using LLMs for knowledge graph creation (Tra-
janoska et al., 2023) and completion (Yao et al., 2023), as well as for the extraction of causal

entities.name: VECTOR SPACE
entities.description: A mathematical space in which similar positions represent similar semantics, used for embedding text chunks and queries

entities.name: QUERIES
entities.description: Search or information retrieval requests that are embedded into the same vector space as text chunks

entities.name: LLM
entities.description: Large Language Models, which have a context window that can be exceeded by external datasets

chunk:
RAG is a developing research area, with multiple
directions already established. These include using LLMs for knowledge graph creation (Tra-
janoska et al., 2023) and completion (Yao et al., 2023), as well as for the extraction of causal
graphs (Ban et al., 2023; Zhang et al., 2024) from source texts. They also include forms of ad-
vanced RAG (Gao et al., 2023) where the index is a knowledge graph (KAPING, Baek et al., 2023),
where subsets of the graph structure (G-Retriever, He et al., 2024) or derived graph metrics (Graph-
ToolFormer, Zhang, 2023) are the objects of enquiry, where narrative outputs are strongly grounded
in the facts of retrieved subgraphs (SURGE, Kang et al., 2023), where retrieved event-plot sub-
graphs are serialized using narrative templates (FABULA, Ranade and Joshi, 2023), and where the
system supports both creation and traversal of text-relationship graphs for multi-hop question an-
swering (Wang et al., 2023b). In terms of open-source software, a variety a graph databases are
supported by both the LangChain (LangChain, 2024) and LlamaIndex (LlamaIndex, 2024) libraries,
while a more general class of graph-based RAG applications is also emerging, including systems that
can create and reason over knowledge graphs in both Neo4J (NaLLM, Neo4J, 2024) and Nebula-
Graph (GraphRAG, NebulaGraph, 2024) formats. Unlike our Graph RAG approach, however, none
of these systems use the natural modularity of graphs to partition data for global summarization.
5 Discussion
Limitations of evaluation approach . Our evaluation to date has only examined a certain class of
sensemaking questions for two corpora in the region of 1 million tokens. More work is needed
to understand how performance varies across different ranges of question types, data types, and
dataset sizes, as well as to validate our sensemaking questions and target metrics with end users.
Comparison of fabrication rates, e.g., using approaches like SelfCheckGPT (Manakul et al., 2023),
would also improve on the current analysis.
Trade-offs of building a graph index . We consistently observed

chunk:
dataset sizes, as well as to validate our sensemaking questions and target metrics with end users.
Comparison of fabrication rates, e.g., using approaches like SelfCheckGPT (Manakul et al., 2023),
would also improve on the current analysis.
Trade-offs of building a graph index . We consistently observed Graph RAG achieve the best head-
to-head results against other methods, but in many cases the graph-free approach to global summa-
rization of source texts performed competitively. The real-world decision about whether to invest in
building a graph index depends on multiple factors, including the compute budget, expected number
of lifetime queries per dataset, and value obtained from other aspects of the graph index (including
the generic community summaries and the use of other graph-related RAG approaches).
Future work . The graph index, rich text annotations, and hierarchical community structure support-
ing the current Graph RAG approach offer many possibilities for refinement and adaptation. This
includes RAG approaches that operate in a more local manner, via embedding-based matching of
user queries and graph annotations, as well as the possibility of hybrid RAG schemes that combine
embedding-based matching against community reports before employing our map-reduce summa-
rization mechanisms. This “roll-up” operation could also be extended across more levels of the
community hierarchy, as well as implemented as a more exploratory “drill down” mechanism that
follows the information scent contained in higher-level community summaries.
6 Conclusion
We have presented a global approach to Graph RAG, combining knowledge graph generation,
retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and query-focused summarization (QFS) to support human
sensemaking over entire text corpora. Initial evaluations show substantial improvements over a
na¨ıve RAG baseline for both the comprehensiveness and diversity of answers, as well as favorable
comparisons to a global but graph-free approach using map-reduce source text summarization. For
situations requiring many global queries over the same dataset, summaries of root-level communi-
ties in the entity-based graph index provide a data index that is both superior to na ¨ıve RAG and
achieves competitive performance to other global methods at a fraction of the token cost.
An open-source, Python-based implementation of both global and local Graph RAG approaches is
forthcoming at https://aka .ms/graphrag .
11Acknowledgements
We would also like to thank the following people who contributed to the work: Alonso

entities.description: Graph RAG is a method that combines knowledge graph generation, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and query-focused summarization (QFS) to support human sensemaking over text corpora

entities.name: GRAPH INDEX
entities.description: A graph index is a structure used in Graph RAG to achieve better summarization results and support various graph-related RAG approaches

entities.description: Global summarization refers to summarizing source texts without using a graph-based approach

entities.description: Community summaries are generic summaries generated from the graph index, useful for various graph-related RAG approaches

entities.name: RICH TEXT ANNOTATIONS

entities.name: HIERARCHICAL COMMUNITY STRUCTURE
entities.description: Hierarchical community structure supports the Graph RAG approach by organizing information in a layered manner

entities.name: EMBEDDING-BASED MATCHING
entities.description: Embedding-based matching is a technique for matching user queries with graph annotations in a more local manner

entities.name: MAP-REDUCE SUMMARIZATION
entities.description: Map-reduce summarization is a method used for summarizing source texts in a global but graph-free approach

entities.name: QUERY-FOCUSED SUMMARIZATION (QFS)
entities.description: Query-focused summarization (QFS) is a technique used in Graph RAG to generate summaries based on specific queries

entities.name: NAÏVE RAG
entities.description: Naïve RAG is a baseline method for retrieval-augmented generation that does not use advanced techniques like graph indexing

entities.name: TEXT CORPORA
entities.description: Text corpora refer to large collections of texts used for analysis and summarization in Graph RAG

entities.name: TOKEN COST
entities.description: Token cost refers to the computational cost associated with processing tokens in summarization methods

entities.name: ALONSO

entities.name: TARGET METRICS
entities.description: Target metrics are specific measurements used to evaluate the performance of a system or approach

entities.name: FABRICATION RATES
entities.description: Fabrication rates refer to the frequency of generating false or misleading information

entities.name: TRADE-OFFS
entities.description: Trade-offs refer to the balancing of different factors when making a decision, such as building a graph index

entities.name: HEAD-TO-HEAD RESULTS
entities.description: Head-to-head results are direct comparisons between different methods or approaches

entities.name: SOURCE TEXTS

entities.name: REAL-WORLD DECISION

entities.name: HYBRID RAG SCHEMES
entities.description: Hybrid RAG schemes combine different approaches, such as embedding-based matching and map-reduce summarization

entities.name: ROLL-UP OPERATION
entities.description: Roll-up operation is a method for summarizing information across multiple levels of a hierarchy

entities.name: DRILL DOWN MECHANISM
entities.description: Drill down mechanism is a method for exploring detailed information by following higher-level summaries

key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="SENSEMAKING QUESTIONS">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT, QUESTION</data>      <data key="d1">Sensemaking questions are queries designed to help understand and interpret data</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="TARGET METRICS">      <data key="d0">METRIC, FACTOR</data>      <data key="d1">Target metrics are specific measurements used to evaluate the performance of a system or approach</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="FABRICATION RATES">      <data key="d0">METRIC, FACTOR</data>      <data key="d1">Fabrication rates refer to the frequency of generating false or misleading information</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="TRADE-OFFS">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT, PHENOMENON</data>      <data key="d1">Trade-offs refer to the balancing of different factors when making a decision, such as building a graph index</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="HEAD-TO-HEAD RESULTS">      <data key="d0">METRIC, FACTOR</data>      <data key="d1">Head-to-head results are direct comparisons between different methods or approaches</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="SOURCE TEXTS">      <data key="d0">DATA, COLLECTION</data>      <data key="d1">Source texts are the original texts used for summarization and analysis</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="REAL-WORLD DECISION">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT, PHENOMENON</data>      <data key="d1">Real-world decision refers to practical choices made based on multiple factors</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="FUTURE WORK">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT, PHENOMENON</data>      <data key="d1">Future work refers to potential areas of research and development for improving the current approach</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="HYBRID RAG SCHEMES">      <data key="d0">TECHNOLOGY, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Hybrid RAG schemes combine different approaches, such as embedding-based matching and map-reduce summarization</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="ROLL-UP OPERATION">      <data key="d0">TECHNIQUE, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Roll-up operation is a method for summarizing information across multiple levels of a hierarchy</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="DRILL DOWN MECHANISM">      <data key="d0">TECHNIQUE, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Drill down mechanism is a method for exploring detailed information by following higher-level summaries</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="CONCLUSION">      <data key="d0">SECTION, PART</data>      <data key="d1">The conclusion summarizes the findings and implications of the study</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="KNOWLEDGE GRAPH GENERATION">      <data key="d0">TECHNIQUE, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Knowledge graph generation is a process used in Graph RAG to create structured representations of information</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="RETRIEVAL-AUGMENTED GENERATION (RAG)">      <data key="d0">TECHNIQUE, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is a technique that combines information retrieval with text generation</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="INITIAL EVALUATIONS">      <data key="d0">PROCESS, METHOD</data>      <data key="d1">Initial evaluations refer to the preliminary assessments of the performance of a method or <data key="d0">METRIC, FACTOR</data>      <data key="d1">Diversity of answers refers to the variety of responses generated by a method</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="OPEN-SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION">      <data key="d0">TECHNOLOGY, TOOL</data>      <data key="d1">An open-source implementation is a key="d0">TECHNOLOGY, TOOL</data>      <data key="d1">A Python-based implementation is a version of a software tool or method developed using the Python programming language</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <node id="ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS">      <data key="d0">SECTION, PART</data>      <data key="d1">The acknowledgements section thanks individuals who contributed to the work</data>      <data key="d2">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </node>    <edge source="SELFHECKGPT" target="GRAPHRAG">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">SelfCheckGPT is mentioned as an approach for comparing fabrication rates, which could improve the current analysis involving Graph RAG</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SELFHECKGPT" target="FABRICATION RATES">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">SelfCheckGPT is mentioned as an approach for comparing fabrication rates</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="GRAPH INDEX">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG uses a graph index to achieve better summarization results and support various graph-related RAG approaches</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="GLOBAL SUMMARIZATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG is compared to global summarization methods that do not use a graph-based approach</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="RICH TEXT ANNOTATIONS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Rich text annotations support the current Graph RAG approach</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="HIERARCHICAL COMMUNITY STRUCTURE">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Hierarchical community structure supports the current Graph RAG approach</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="EMBEDDING-BASED MATCHING">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Future work on Graph RAG includes embedding-based matching of user queries and graph annotations</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="MAP-REDUCE SUMMARIZATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG is compared to a global but graph-free approach using map-reduce source text summarization</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="QUERY-FOCUSED SUMMARIZATION (QFS)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG combines query-focused summarization (QFS) to support human sensemaking over text corpora</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="NAÏVE RAG">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Initial evaluations show Graph RAG has substantial improvements over a naïve RAG baseline</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="TEXT CORPORA">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG supports human sensemaking over entire text corpora</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="TOKEN COST">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG achieves competitive performance to other global methods at a fraction of the token cost</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="ALONSO">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Alonso is acknowledged for contributing to the work on Graph RAG</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="HEAD-TO-HEAD RESULTS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG achieves the best head-to-head results against other methods</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="FUTURE WORK">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Future work includes possibilities for refining and adapting the Graph RAG approach</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="HYBRID RAG SCHEMES">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Future work includes the possibility of hybrid RAG schemes that combine different approaches</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="ROLL-UP OPERATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The roll-up operation could be extended across more levels of the community hierarchy in Graph RAG</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="DRILL DOWN MECHANISM">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The drill down mechanism could be implemented to follow information scent in higher-level community summaries in Graph RAG</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="CONCLUSION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The conclusion summarizes the findings and implications of the Graph RAG study</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="KNOWLEDGE GRAPH GENERATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG combines knowledge graph generation to support human sensemaking</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="RETRIEVAL-AUGMENTED GENERATION (RAG)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG combines retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) to support human sensemaking</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="INITIAL EVALUATIONS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Initial evaluations show substantial improvements of Graph RAG over a naïve RAG baseline</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="COMPREHENSIVENESS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG shows substantial improvements in the comprehensiveness of answers</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="DIVERSITY OF ANSWERS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Graph RAG shows substantial improvements in the diversity of answers</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="OPEN-SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">An open-source implementation of Graph RAG is forthcoming</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="PYTHON-BASED IMPLEMENTATION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">A Python-based implementation of Graph RAG is forthcoming</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPHRAG" target="ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The acknowledgements section thanks individuals who contributed to the work on Graph RAG</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPH INDEX" target="COMPUTE BUDGET">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The decision to invest in building a graph index depends on factors like the compute budget</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPH INDEX" target="LIFETIME QUERIES">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The decision to invest in building a graph index depends on factors like the expected number of lifetime queries per dataset</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPH INDEX" target="COMMUNITY SUMMARIES">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The value obtained from a graph index includes the generation of community summaries</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPH INDEX" target="TRADE-OFFS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Trade-offs are considered when deciding whether to invest in building a graph index</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRAPH INDEX" target="REAL-WORLD DECISION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The real-world decision to invest in a graph index depends on multiple factors</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GLOBAL SUMMARIZATION" target="SOURCE TEXTS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Global summarization involves summarizing source texts without using a graph-based approach</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATASET SIZES" target="SENSEMAKING QUESTIONS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Dataset sizes are used to validate sensemaking questions</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATASET SIZES" target="TARGET METRICS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Dataset sizes are used to validate target metrics</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SENSEMAKING QUESTIONS" target="TARGET METRICS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Sensemaking questions and target metrics are validated with end users</data>      <data key="d5">e4d9b12cf2b4c691c74019eefff4fb39</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

An open-source, Python-based implementation of both global and local Graph RAG approaches is
forthcoming at https://aka .ms/graphrag .
11Acknowledgements
We would also like to thank the following people who contributed to the work: Alonso Guevara
Fern ´andez, Amber Hoak, Andr ´es Morales Esquivel, Ben Cutler, Billie Rinaldi, Chris Sanchez,
Chris Trevino, Christine Caggiano, David Tittsworth, Dayenne de Souza, Douglas Orbaker, Ed
Clark, Gabriel Nieves-Ponce, Gaudy Blanco Meneses, Kate Lytvynets, Katy Smith, M ´onica Carva-
jal, Nathan Evans, Richard Ortega, Rodrigo Racanicci, Sarah Smith, and Shane Solomon.
References
Achiam, J., Adler, S., Agarwal, S., Ahmad, L., Akkaya, I., Aleman, F. L., Almeida, D., Al-
tenschmidt, J., Altman, S., Anadkat, S., et al. (2023). Gpt-4 technical report. arXiv preprint
arXiv:2303.08774 .
Anil, R., Borgeaud, S., Wu, Y ., Alayrac, J.-B., Yu, J., Soricut, R., Schalkwyk, J., Dai, A. M.,
Hauth, A., et al. (2023). Gemini: a family of highly capable multimodal models. arXiv preprint
arXiv:2312.11805 .
Baek, J., Aji, A. F., and Saffari, A. (2023). Knowledge-augmented language model prompting for
zero-shot knowledge graph question answering. arXiv preprint arXiv:2306.04136 .
Ban, T., Chen, L., Wang, X., and Chen, H. (2023). From query tools to causal architects: Harnessing
large language models for advanced causal discovery from data.
Baumel, T., Eyal, M., and Elhadad, M. (2018). Query focused abstractive summarization: Incorpo-
rating query relevance, multi-document coverage, and summary length constraints into seq2seq
models. arXiv preprint arXiv:180

entities.name: AUGMENTED RETRIEVAL

entities.name: ITERATIVE RETRIEVAL-GENERATION SYNERGY
entities.description: A method to enhance retrieval-augmented large language models by iteratively improving the retrieval and generation processes, discussed in the paper "Enhancing retrieval-augmented large language models with iterative retrieval-generation synergy"

chunk:
Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  
The Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity Research  
 
 
Editors:  
Sonia Jaffe, Neha Parikh Shah, Jenna Butler, Alex Farach, Alexia Cambon, Brent Hecht , Michael Schwarz, and Jaime Teevan   
Contributing Researchers :  
Reid Andersen, Margarita Bermejo -Cano, James Bono, Georg Buscher, Chacha Chen, Steven Clarke, Scott Counts , Eleanor Dillon,  
Ben Edelman, Ulrike Gruber -Gremlich, Cory Hilke, Ben Hanrahan, Sandra Ho, Brian Houck, Mansi Khemka,  Viktor Kewenig, 
Madeline Kleiner, Eric Knudsen, Sathish Manivannan, Max Meijer, Jennifer Neville, Nam Ngo, Donald Ngwe, Ried Peckham, Sida 
Peng, Nora Presson,  Nagu Rangan , Reetchatha Rangareddy , Sean Rintel, Roberto Rodriguez, Katie Rotella, Tara Safavi,  Advait 
Sarkar, Ava Elizabeth Scott, Abigail Sellen, Chirag Shah, Auste Simkute, Tyler Smith, Shwetha Srinath, Siddharth Suri, An-Jen 
Tai, Lev Tankelevitch, Mengting Wan, Leijie Wang , Ryen White, and Longqi Yang   
(with additional support from the entire AI and Productivity team at Microsoft)  
ABSTRACT  
This report presents the most recent findings of Microsoft’s 
research initiative on AI and Productivity , which seeks to measure 
and understand  the productivity gains associated with LLM -
powered productivity tools like Microsoft Copilot. The report 
synthesizes research results from over a dozen  recent studies 
conducted by researchers at Microsoft, with a focus on studies of 
generative AI in actual workplace  environments . One of these is, to 
our knowledge , the largest , randomized controlled trial of the 
introduction of generative AI into organizations.  Overall, the 
research suggests that generative AI is already aiding workers in 
becoming more productive in their day -to-day jobs in significant 
ways. However, t he influence of generative AI is subject to 
variation by role, function, and organization and is contingent upon 
adoption and utilization. The report explores these variations and 
underscores the potential for AI to h ave even greater impact as 
individual

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, based on input data

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company that conducts research on AI and productivity, and develops productivity tools like Microsoft Copilot

entities.name: AI AND PRODUCTIVITY RESEARCH
entities.description: A research initiative by Microsoft aimed at measuring and understanding the productivity gains associated with LLM-powered productivity tools

entities.name: MICROSOFT COPILOT
entities.description: A productivity tool powered by large language models (LLMs) developed by Microsoft to aid workers in their day-to-day jobs

entities.name: WORKPLACE ENVIRONMENTS
entities.description: Actual work settings where generative AI tools are implemented and studied to understand their impact on productivity

entities.name: RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL
entities.description: A type of study conducted by Microsoft to evaluate the introduction of generative AI into organizations

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY GAINS
entities.description: The improvements in efficiency and effectiveness in work tasks attributed to the use of generative AI tools

entities.name: ROLE, FUNCTION, AND ORGANIZATION
entities.description: Different aspects that influence the effectiveness and impact of generative AI on productivity in the workplace

chunk:
their day -to-day jobs in significant 
ways. However, t he influence of generative AI is subject to 
variation by role, function, and organization and is contingent upon 
adoption and utilization. The report explores these variations and 
underscores the potential for AI to h ave even greater impact as 
individuals and organizations recalibrate their work practices to 
harness AI in the places where it provides the most value . 
 
Please cite this report as:  
Jaffe, S., Shah, N.P., Butler, J., Farach, A., Cambon, A., Hecht, B., 
Schwarz, M. and Teevan, J. eds. 2024. Generative AI in Real -World 
Workplaces: The Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity 
Research. Microsoft.  
1 INTRODUCTION  
There is tremendous  interest in how AI can increase people’s 
productivity at work. To help meet this interest, in December 2023, 
Microsoft released a first AI and Productivity Report  (Cambon et 
al. 2023) synthesizing the results of many Microsoft studies on AI 
and productivity. These studies contributed to a large and growing 
literature from around the world and a wide variety of disciplines. 
Although there are exceptions, this literature largely points to a 
broad conclusion: Generative AI tools have the potential to 
introduce  a substantial step -function increase in productivity for tasks performed by information workers (e.g. , Noy and Zhang 
2023; Dell’Acqua et al. 2023; Brynjolfsson et al. 2023; Peng et al. 
2023). 
 
However, much of this existing literature on AI and productivity is 
limited in that it consists primarily of lab-based studies. In these 
studies, participants use d generative AI tools to complete 
researcher -designed tasks in a controlled, simulated work 
environment , largely with a focus on tasks that the researchers 
hypothesized would be amenable to generative AI. Now that a 
much larger population of workers has access to generative AI 
tools, we can begin to understand the impact of these tools outside 
of a lab setting, as people perform their everyday jobs. This has 
begun to allow researchers at Microsoft and elsewhere to study how 
the first wave of generative AI tools impacts information work in 
real-world contexts.  
 
Accordingly, this second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, based on input data

entities.name: ROLE
entities.description: A specific position or function within an organization that can be influenced by generative AI

entities.name: FUNCTION
entities.description: A specific activity or set of activities within an organization that can be influenced by generative AI

entities.name: ORGANIZATION
entities.description: A structured group of people with a common purpose, which can be influenced by generative AI

entities.name: ADOPTION
entities.description: The process of starting to use generative AI tools within an organization or by individuals

entities.name: UTILIZATION
entities.description: The manner in which generative AI tools are used within an organization or by individuals

entities.name: REPORT
entities.description: A document exploring the variations in the influence of generative AI and its potential impact on work practices

chunk:
impact of these tools outside 
of a lab setting, as people perform their everyday jobs. This has 
begun to allow researchers at Microsoft and elsewhere to study how 
the first wave of generative AI tools impacts information work in 
real-world contexts.  
 
Accordingly, this second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report 
focuses on Microsoft studies that explore how people apply Copilot  
and other generative AI tools  to their regular work. The report also 
describes learnings from a small set of additional lab experiments 
that suggest new ways that we might see the impact of Copilot in -
the-wild in future studies. Overall, the results – including those 
from what we believe is the single largest randomized controlled 
trial on the introduction of generative AI in real  workplaces – point 
to several high -level observations:  
 
• Generative AI is already helping people be measurably more  
productive in their day -to-day jobs. 
• As expected, the productivity story in real -world workflows 
is more complex than observed in lab studies.   
• Productivity gains associated with generative  AI, including 
time and accuracy, vary by role, function and organization . 
• Variance in adoption and utilization influen ces AI’s impact. 
• Early studies suggest generative  AI may affect the cognitive 
effort required for task completion.   Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
2 
 The goal of th is report is to synthesize learnings from studies from 
around the company versus to completely describe each individual 
study. Many of the studies are or will be the subject of dedicated 
reports or research papers , and we have provided links to those 
documents where they are already available. Most of the studies 
have not yet been through peer review and as such they have not 
had the chance thus far to incorporate external reviewer feedback. 
Further, before continuing , it is important to acknowledge that all 
work here was funded by Microsoft, which has a commercial 
interest in improving and demonstrating the degree to which 
Copilot increases worker productivity.  
2 RELATED WORK  
Researchers outside of Microsoft also have been moving to study 
generative AI ’s impact on productivity in real-world contexts. This 
section highlights a few of the most notable studies in this space . 
These studies  consistently show that the gains predicted by  lab 
studies do indeed translate into significant impact when AI is used 
for real work . Further, they begin to reveal  some nuances in how

entities.name: LAB SETTING
entities.description: A controlled environment where tasks are studied to hypothesize the performance of generative AI

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: A technology company involved in studying the impact of generative AI tools on information work in real-world contexts

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI TOOLS
entities.description: Artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, based on input data, used to enhance productivity in various tasks

entities.name: INFORMATION WORK
entities.description: A variety of tasks, often unstructured and informal, that are part of people's jobs and are impacted by generative AI tools

entities.name: MICROSOFT AI AND PRODUCTIVITY REPORT
entities.description: A report focusing on Microsoft studies that explore how people apply Copilot and other generative AI tools to their regular work

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: A generative AI tool developed by Microsoft to assist with various tasks and improve productivity

entities.name: LAB EXPERIMENTS
entities.description: Controlled studies conducted in a lab setting to observe the impact of generative AI tools like Copilot

entities.name: RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL
entities.description: A study design used to measure the impact of generative AI tools in real workplaces, considered to be one of the largest of its kind

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: The efficiency and effectiveness with which tasks are completed, often measured in terms of time and accuracy

entities.name: COGNITIVE EFFORT
entities.description: The mental effort required to complete tasks, which may be affected by the use of generative AI tools

entities.name: JAFFE ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study referenced in the report that discusses the cognitive effort required for task completion when using generative AI

entities.name: PEER REVIEW
entities.description: The process of evaluating academic work by external reviewers to ensure quality and validity

entities.name: COMMERCIAL INTEREST
entities.description: The financial and business motivations behind Microsoft's funding of studies on Copilot's impact on productivity

entities.name: RELATED WORK
entities.description: A section in the report that highlights notable studies by researchers outside of Microsoft on the impact of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: REAL-WORLD CONTEXTS
entities.description: Natural settings where generative AI tools are used in everyday jobs, as opposed to controlled lab environments

entities.name: RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Individuals involved in studying the impact of generative AI tools on information work in real-world contexts

entities.name: FIRST WAVE OF GENERATIVE AI TOOLS
entities.description: The initial versions of generative AI tools that are being studied for their impact on productivity

entities.name: SECOND MICROSOFT AI AND PRODUCTIVITY REPORT
entities.description: A follow-up report focusing on Microsoft studies that explore how people apply Copilot and other generative AI tools to their regular work

entities.name: HIGH-LEVEL OBSERVATIONS
entities.description: Key findings from the studies on the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: ROLE
entities.description: The specific job or function of an individual, which can influence the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: FUNCTION
entities.description: The specific activities or tasks performed within an organization, which can influence the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: ORGANIZATION
entities.description: A group or entity where generative AI tools are applied, influencing their impact on productivity

entities.name: ADOPTION
entities.description: The process of starting to use generative AI tools, which influences their impact on productivity

entities.name: UTILIZATION
entities.description: The extent to which generative AI tools are used, which influences their impact on productivity

entities.name: STUDIES
entities.description: Research conducted to understand the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: DEDICATED REPORTS
entities.description: Specific reports or research papers that focus on individual studies of generative AI tools

entities.name: RESEARCH PAPERS
entities.description: Academic papers that describe studies on the impact of generative AI tools

entities.name: EXTERNAL REVIEWER FEEDBACK
entities.description: Feedback from external reviewers that helps validate the findings of studies on generative AI tools

entities.name: FUNDING
entities.description: Financial support provided by Microsoft for studies on the impact of Copilot and other generative AI tools

entities.name: NOTABLE STUDIES
entities.description: Significant research conducted by researchers outside of Microsoft on the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: GAINS
entities.description: Improvements in productivity observed when using generative AI tools

chunk:
on productivity in real-world contexts. This 
section highlights a few of the most notable studies in this space . 
These studies  consistently show that the gains predicted by  lab 
studies do indeed translate into significant impact when AI is used 
for real work . Further, they begin to reveal  some nuances in how 
AI is used , highlighting the importance of contextual factors such 
as skill or task selection on AI’s impact and providing early 
evidence that the presence of AI may impact people’s behavior  and 
the larger ecosystem . 
 
Brynjolfsson et al . (2023) introduced  one of the earliest studies of 
generative AI in real-world work environments. They stud ied an 
AI-based conversational assistant for customer service agents in a 
call center , and found that agents with the assistant resolved 14% 
more issues per hour than those without the assistant. Consistent 
with what has been observed in some lab studies (e.g., Noy and 
Zhang 2023), t he largest impact was on novice and low -skilled 
workers, with very little effect on experience d or highly -skilled 
workers. 
 
However, observing larger benefits for less-skilled workers is 
certainly not universal . Otis et al. ( 2024) examined the effects of a 
generative AI -powered entrepreneurship support tool  on Kenyan 
entrepreneurs’ business performance via an index measure based 
on profit and revenue . They found that entrepreneurs with above -
median performance prior to the start of the experiment saw gains 
of 0.19 standard deviations in performance when using the AI tool, 
while entrepreneurs with below -median performance  saw a 
decrease of 0.09 standard deviations. Though the two groups used 
the tool similar amounts, they tended to ask different types of 
questions. This finding  emphasizes  the importance of contextual 
factors in the productivity gains seen by using generative AI, a key 
observation of this report as well.  
 
In addition , some early real -world studies show that the presence 
of AI may have cascading effects , not just affecting productivity on 
a given task, but also changing which tasks people choose to do.  
For example, Wiles and Horton (202 4) explored how having an 
LLM generat e a first draft of a job posting affected postings and 
hiring on a large online labor market. They f ound that the AI tool 
decre

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency with which tasks and work are completed, often measured in terms of output per unit of input

entities.name: REAL-WORLD CONTEXTS
entities.description: Real-world contexts refer to practical, everyday environments where tasks and activities are performed outside of controlled lab settings

entities.name: LAB STUDIES
entities.description: Lab studies are controlled experiments conducted in a laboratory setting to test hypotheses and observe outcomes under specific conditions

entities.name: AI
entities.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to systems and technologies that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, and problem-solving

entities.name: CONTEXTUAL FACTORS
entities.description: Contextual factors are the various conditions and circumstances that can influence the effectiveness and impact of AI, such as skill level and task selection

entities.name: BEHAVIOR
entities.description: Behavior refers to the actions and reactions of individuals in response to external or internal stimuli, which can be influenced by the presence of AI

entities.name: ECOSYSTEM
entities.description: The ecosystem refers to the larger system or environment in which AI operates, including all interacting entities and factors

entities.name: BRYNJOLFSSON ET AL. (2023)
entities.description: A study conducted by Brynjolfsson and colleagues in 2023, focusing on the use of generative AI in real-world work environments

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, based on input data

entities.name: AI-BASED CONVERSATIONAL ASSISTANT
entities.description: An AI tool designed to assist customer service agents by providing conversational support to help resolve issues

entities.name: CUSTOMER SERVICE AGENTS
entities.description: Individuals who assist customers by addressing their inquiries and resolving issues, often in a call center environment

entities.name: CALL CENTER
entities.description: A centralized office where customer service agents handle a large volume of telephone calls

entities.name: NOY AND ZHANG (2023)
entities.description: A study conducted by Noy and Zhang in 2023, observing the impact of AI in lab settings

entities.name: NOVICE WORKERS
entities.description: Workers who are new or have little experience in their field

entities.name: LOW-SKILLED WORKERS
entities.description: Workers who have limited skills or training in their field

entities.name: EXPERIENCED WORKERS
entities.description: Workers who have significant experience and expertise in their field

entities.name: HIGHLY-SKILLED WORKERS
entities.description: Workers who possess advanced skills and training in their field

entities.name: OTIS ET AL. (2024)
entities.description: A study conducted by Otis and colleagues in 2024, examining the effects of a generative AI-powered entrepreneurship support tool on Kenyan entrepreneurs

entities.name: ENTREPRENEURSHIP SUPPORT TOOL
entities.description: A generative AI tool designed to assist entrepreneurs in improving their business performance

entities.name: KENYAN ENTREPRENEURS
entities.description: Entrepreneurs based in Kenya who are involved in starting and running businesses

entities.name: BUSINESS PERFORMANCE
entities.description: A measure of the success and efficiency of a business, often evaluated through metrics such as profit and revenue

entities.name: WILES AND HORTON (2024)
entities.description: A study conducted by Wiles and Horton in 2024, exploring the impact of an LLM-generated first draft of job postings on an online labor market

entities.name: LLM
entities.description: Large Language Model, a type of AI that can generate human-like text based on input data

entities.name: JOB POSTING
entities.description: A public announcement of a job vacancy, detailing the responsibilities, requirements, and application process

entities.name: ONLINE LABOR MARKET
entities.description: A digital platform where employers and job seekers interact to fill job vacancies

entities.name: STUDIES
entities.description: Studies refer to systematic investigations conducted to establish facts or principles or to collect information on a subject

entities.name: GAINS
entities.description: Gains refer to improvements or increases in performance, productivity, or other metrics

entities.name: SKILL
entities.description: Skill refers to the ability to perform tasks well, often acquired through training or experience

entities.name: TASK SELECTION
entities.description: Task selection refers to the process of choosing specific tasks to perform, which can influence the impact of AI

entities.name: EVIDENCE
entities.description: Evidence refers to information or data that supports a conclusion or hypothesis

entities.name: BRYNJOLFSSON ET AL.
entities.description: Brynjolfsson and colleagues are the authors of a study conducted in 2023 on generative AI in real-world work environments

entities.name: ISSUES
entities.description: Issues refer to problems or challenges that need to be resolved, often in a customer service context

entities.name: RESOLUTION RATE
entities.description: Resolution rate refers to the number of issues resolved per unit of time, often used as a productivity metric

entities.name: OTIS ET AL.
entities.description: Otis and colleagues are the authors of a study conducted in 2024 on the effects of a generative AI-powered entrepreneurship support tool

entities.name: PROFIT
entities.description: Profit refers to the financial gain made in a business after subtracting expenses from revenue

entities.name: REVENUE
entities.description: Revenue refers to the total income generated by a business from its operations

entities.name: PERFORMANCE INDEX
entities.description: Performance index is a composite measure used to evaluate business performance, often based on metrics like profit and revenue

entities.name: WILES AND HORTON
entities.description: Wiles and Horton are the authors of a study conducted in 2024 on the impact of an LLM-generated first draft of job postings

entities.name: HIRING
entities.description: Hiring refers to the process of finding and recruiting employees for job positions

chunk:
but also changing which tasks people choose to do.  
For example, Wiles and Horton (202 4) explored how having an 
LLM generat e a first draft of a job posting affected postings and 
hiring on a large online labor market. They f ound that the AI tool 
decreased time spent writing posts and increase d the number of posts completed but  had no effect on the number of hires. The 
researchers suggest this may be because the additional jobs that get 
posted were less important than their other jobs and using AI to 
draft may have caused employers to  exert less effort in writing the 
job posts, leaving them with fewer well -matched applicants.  In 
another example, Yeverechyahu et al . (2024) studied generative AI 
effects on coding activity, both quantity and type . Specifically, the 
authors compared  open-source repositories for packages in Python 
(which was supported by GitHub Copilot) to R (which was not). 
They found a significant jump in contributions due to GitHub 
Copilot. Of note, the increase was larger for contributions  
categorized as “maintenance solutions” than for those categorized 
as “new code development ,” which require more extrapolative 
thinking.  
 
In addition to impacting human behavior, t he real-world presence 
of generative AI may also influence the future behavior of AI 
systems themselves . Rio-Chanona et al. (2023) provide evidence 
that the availability of generative AI programming tools 
substantially reduced participation in online programming forums 
that produce important training data for these tools . This suggests 
that in some contexts  a “paradox of reuse” dynamics (Taraborelli 
2015; McMahon  et al. 2017) might be emerging in the generative 
AI ecosystem. These dynamics could significantly harm 
productivity ga ins if not properly addressed  (Vincent 2022).  
3 STUDIES AND RESULTS  
We now provide an overview of  studies recently conducted  by 
researchers at Microsoft , focusing in particular on those that speak 
to real-world implications of generative AI.  
Studies of workers using AI on the job  
Early Access Program Telemetry Study (Eleanor Dillon, Sonia 
Jaffe, Sida Peng , and Alexia Cambon ) 
Working with over 60 organizations and including over 6000 
individual employees across a wide range of industries and 
occupations, researchers  conducted a large-scale randomized 
controlled

chunk:
job  
Early Access Program Telemetry Study (Eleanor Dillon, Sonia 
Jaffe, Sida Peng , and Alexia Cambon ) 
Working with over 60 organizations and including over 6000 
individual employees across a wide range of industries and 
occupations, researchers  conducted a large-scale randomized 
controlled field experiment of Copilot for M icrosoft 365 – relying 
on participants using the tool in their day -to-day work as opposed 
to on researcher -defined tasks in a lab context. We believe this 
research is the largest controlled study of productivity impacts in 
real-world generative AI deployments to date.   
Researchers worked with  organizations in the Copilot for Microsoft 
365 (M365) Early Access Program to create a randomized control 
trial. Copilot for Microsoft 365  combines  generative AI tools in 
applications such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, Teams, 
and others. Each organization set aside at least 50 licenses to be 
randomly assigned among 100 or more M icrosoft 365 users 
nominated  by the organization . Researchers partnered closely with 
IT administrators and business decision -makers in each of the over 
60 participating organizations to explain the need for 
randomization and obtain buy -in. To ensure privacy, r esearchers Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
3 
 looked only at aggregate effects and did not analyze or report 
individual -level data . 
 
Using metadata from M icrosoft 365 in these organizations, 
researchers compared how email, meeting, and document behavior 
differed based on being assigned a Copilot license. Researchers 
found that on average,  those with Copilot for Microsoft 365  read 
11% fewer individual emails and spent 4% less time interacting 
with them, compared to people without Copilot. Some 
organizations saw larger effects with relative decreases of up to 20 
or 25% in both emails read and time spent interacting with email. 
The top grap h in Figure 1 shows the effects across organizations. 
The researchers hypothesize that  the summarize emails feature in 
Copilot for Outlook and the Copilot chat function may have 
allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or 
rereading individual  emails. 
 
The effects of Copilot on the number of meetings attended (via 
Microsoft  Teams) were more complex, with some organizations 
seeing significant increases , others seeing significant decreases , 
and others seeing no significant effect .

entities.name: EARLY ACCESS PROGRAM TELEMETRY STUDY
entities.description: A large-scale randomized controlled field experiment conducted by Eleanor Dillon, Sonia Jaffe, Sida Peng, and Alexia Cambon, involving over 60 organizations and 6000 individual employees to study the productivity impacts of Copilot for Microsoft 365

entities.name: ELEANOR DILLON
entities.description: Eleanor Dillon is one of the researchers involved in the Early Access Program Telemetry Study

entities.name: COPILOT FOR MICROSOFT 365
entities.description: A generative AI tool integrated into Microsoft 365 applications such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, and Teams, used in the Early Access Program Telemetry Study

entities.name: MICROSOFT 365
entities.description: A suite of productivity applications including Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, and Teams, used by organizations in the Early Access Program Telemetry Study

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Over 60 organizations participated in the Early Access Program Telemetry Study, providing at least 50 licenses for Copilot for Microsoft 365 to be randomly assigned among their employees

entities.name: INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYEES
entities.description: Over 6000 individual employees across various industries and occupations participated in the Early Access Program Telemetry Study

entities.name: IT ADMINISTRATORS

entities.name: BUSINESS DECISION-MAKERS
entities.description: Business decision-makers in the participating organizations partnered with researchers to explain the need for randomization and obtain buy-in for the study

entities.name: EMAIL BEHAVIOR
entities.description: The behavior of reading and interacting with emails, which was compared between users with and without Copilot for Microsoft 365 in the study

entities.name: MEETING BEHAVIOR
entities.description: The behavior of attending meetings via Microsoft Teams, which was analyzed in the study to see the effects of Copilot for Microsoft 365

entities.name: DOCUMENT BEHAVIOR
entities.description: The behavior of interacting with documents, which was compared between users with and without Copilot for Microsoft 365 in the study

entities.name: SUMMARIZE EMAILS FEATURE
entities.description: A feature in Copilot for Outlook that may have allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or rereading individual emails

entities.name: COPILOT CHAT FUNCTION
entities.description: A chat function in Copilot that may have allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or rereading individual emails

entities.name: MICROSOFT TEAMS
entities.description: A communication platform included in Microsoft 365, used for attending meetings, which was analyzed in the study to see the effects of Copilot for Microsoft 365

entities.name: MICROSOFT TECHNICAL REPORT
entities.description: A report documenting the findings of the Early Access Program Telemetry Study on the productivity impacts of Copilot for Microsoft 365

entities.name: RANDOMIZED CONTROL TRIAL

entities.name: PRIVACY

entities.description: The overall effects observed in the study, as opposed to individual-level data

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY IMPACTS
entities.description: The effects of Copilot for Microsoft 365 on productivity, which were the focus of the study

entities.name: REAL-WORLD GENERATIVE AI DEPLOYMENTS
entities.description: The application of generative AI tools like Copilot for Microsoft 365 in actual work environments, as opposed to lab settings

entities.name: EMAILS READ

function may have 
allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or 
rereading individual  emails. 
 
The effects of Copilot on the number of meetings attended (via 
Microsoft  Teams) were more complex, with some organizations 
seeing significant increases , others seeing significant decreases , 
and others seeing no significant effect . Of the 47 organizations that 
have been in the study the longest, 10 saw a statistically significant 
decrease in attended meetings, with an average decrease of .39 
meetings per day on a pre -Copilot average of 3 meetings. On the 
other hand, 14 customers saw a statistically significa nt increase in 
meetings with an average increase of .36 meetings per day on a pre -
Copilot average of 2 meetings. The difference in baseline average 
suggests that increases  in meetings  attended were more likely at 
organizations with low levels of baseline Teams usage. The 
remaining customers did not see a statistically significant change in 
the number of Teams meetings. The middle graph in Figure 1 plots 
the effect for each customer.  
 
Teams Copilot provides meeting summaries and uses the transcript 
to answer questions users may ask of it during or after a meeting, 
but only works for meetings that are executed in Teams.  Thus, 
having access gives people an additional reason to have meetings 
in Teams (instead of only in -person or via another app) , so 
increases could reflect increases in the use of Teams that are not 
indicative of increases in overall meetings. More generally, if 
Copilot makes meetings both more effective and more efficient , 
that can generate conflicting effects : more efficient meetings 
require less time and fewer follow -up meetings, but if meetings 
become more effective collaboration tools, they may be used for a 
wider range of projects or tasks.  
 
With respect to documents, people with Copilot also created and 
edited more documents than those without Copilot. Overall people 
edited 10% more documents, with heavy users of Word, Excel, and 
PowerPoint seeing an increase of 13% (on a higher baseline). So me 
organizations saw increases in the 25 -30% range. One hypothesis 
is this is an early sign of the writing and creation assistance that 
Copilot provides making it easier to produce  and revise  output. 
Alternatively, people may be using some of the time they save with 
Copilot to do additional document creation and editing.

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a tool that assists users by providing meeting summaries, answering questions during or after meetings, and aiding in document creation and editing

entities.name: MICROSOFT TEAMS
entities.description: Microsoft Teams is a collaboration platform used for meetings and communication within organizations

entities.name: MEETINGS
entities.description: Meetings are organized events where people gather to discuss and collaborate on various topics

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Organizations are groups or entities that participated in the study to observe the effects of Copilot on their activities

entities.name: CUSTOMERS
entities.description: Customers refer to the users or organizations that are using Copilot and are part of the study

entities.name: DOCUMENTS
entities.description: Documents are files created and edited by users, including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files

entities.name: WORD
entities.description: Word is a word processing software used for creating and editing text documents

entities.name: EXCEL
entities.description: Excel is a spreadsheet software used for data organization and analysis

entities.name: POWERPOINT
entities.description: PowerPoint is a presentation software used for creating and editing slideshows

entities.name: STUDY
entities.description: The study is an ongoing research project observing the effects of Copilot on various activities within organizations

entities.name: INFORMATION RETRIEVAL
entities.description: The function of retrieving information without reading or rereading individual emails

entities.name: MEETING SUMMARIES
entities.description: Summaries of meetings provided by Copilot to help users understand the key points discussed

entities.name: TRANSCRIPT
entities.description: A written or printed version of the spoken content during a meeting, used by Copilot to answer questions

entities.name: FOLLOW-UP MEETINGS
entities.description: Additional meetings scheduled to continue discussions or address unresolved issues from previous meetings

entities.name: COLLABORATION TOOLS
entities.description: Tools that facilitate teamwork and communication among team members, such as Microsoft Teams and Copilot

entities.name: WRITING ASSISTANCE
entities.description: The support provided by Copilot to help users in writing and creating documents

entities.name: CREATION ASSISTANCE
entities.description: The support provided by Copilot to help users in creating and editing documents

entities.name: TIME SAVING
entities.description: The reduction in time required to complete tasks due to the assistance provided by Copilot

chunk:
range. One hypothesis 
is this is an early sign of the writing and creation assistance that 
Copilot provides making it easier to produce  and revise  output. 
Alternatively, people may be using some of the time they save with 
Copilot to do additional document creation and editing.   
 This study is still under way , and researchers are planning to 
explore additional outcomes (e.g., amount of time spent per 
document ) as well as  spillovers and team effects  (e.g., the impact 
of a worker’s collaborators having Copilot). This study is limited 
by its focus on work processes. That is, though telemetry can 
provide an objective measure of activity, th ere is not a direct 
mapping between the observed outcomes (number of documents, 
emails, etc) and productivity , performance or business outcomes . 
Moreover , to preserve privacy, the study observes  activity, not the 
content created, so it cannot study quality or how well output aligns 
with people’s goals or intents.  
Work Trend Index Survey  
More study details available in AI at Work Is Here. Now Comes the 
Hard Part  (Microsoft and LinkedIn 2024)  
To understand the impact of generative AI on workplace 
productivity and satisfaction, Microsoft conducted the 2024 Work 
Trend Index Survey. This 20 -minute, anonymous survey was 
administered by Edelman Data & Intelligence to 31,000 full -time 
employed or sel f-employed knowledge workers across 31 countries  
Figure 1. Effects across organizations of access to Copilot for 
M365 on emails read, scheduled meetings attended, and files 
edited in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint .  
 Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
4 
 between February 15, 2024, and March 28, 2024. The survey aimed 
to capture user sentiments and experiences with generative AI 
broadly as opposed to focusing on any specific generative AI tool 
such as Copilot.  
 
One key finding from the survey is the widespread use of 
unsanctioned AI tools among employees. The survey revealed that, 
of respondents who used AI, 78% used  at least some AI tools not 
provided by their organization.  This highlights a significant 
phenomenon where many employees turn to external AI resources 
to meet their needs.  
 
Additionally, a  significant focus of the Work Trend Index data 
analyses is “AI Power Users ,”

chunk:
78% used  at least some AI tools not 
provided by their organization.  This highlights a significant 
phenomenon where many employees turn to external AI resources 
to meet their needs.  
 
Additionally, a  significant focus of the Work Trend Index data 
analyses is “AI Power Users ,” which researchers defined as 
individuals reporting being familiar with generative AI, using it at 
work at least several times a week, and saving more than 30 minutes 
a day by using it . Overall, 29% of respondents who used AI fell into 
this bucket. Power users had noticeably lower use of unsanctioned 
AI (66% vs . the non-power user average of 83%, p<.05) . 
 
Researchers sought to understand which factors from the survey 
were most predictive of the power user classification; they focused 
on several survey questions categorized into three areas:  
• Actions: Actions related to generative AI at work.  
• Methods: Methods of AI usage.  
• Outcomes: Feelings or outcomes related to respondent AI 
usage. 
 
The survey responses were analyzed to build a model identifying 
the key predictors of AI power user classification. The data 
preparation and modeling process included addressing class imbalance using the Synthetic Minority Over -sampling Technique 
(SMOTE) and evaluating model performance through cross -
validation. Researchers implemented two predictive models: 
Random Forest and Logistic Regression. The Random Forest 
model outperformed Log istic Regression with an accuracy of 0.744 
and a ROC -AUC score of 0.737,  compared to Logistic Regression's 
accuracy of 0.657 and ROC -AUC score of 0.695. Consequently, 
the Random Forest model was trained on the entire dataset to 
pinpoint the key predictors of AI power usage.  
 
As seen in Figure 2, regular experimentation with AI emerged as 
the most significant predictor of AI power usage classification. This 
factor was a stronger predictor of power user classification than 
other AI specific methods, actions, or outcomes. The imp ortance 
score, measured by a Random Forest statistical model, should be 
interpreted relatively, as it shows how much each feature helps in 
predicting AI power usage compared to others. Higher scores 
indicate greater importance. In this analysis, scores ran ge from 361 
to 882, highlighting the significant factors influencing AI power 
user classification within this dataset and model.  
 
As with all surveys of this type

indicate greater importance. In this analysis, scores ran ge from 361 
to 882, highlighting the significant factors influencing AI power 
user classification within this dataset and model.  
 
As with all surveys of this type, it is important to view all the above 
results through the lens of the limitations of the methodology. 
While the analysis reveals significant associations, causation 
cannot be conclusively established due to the observational nature 
of the data. Similarly, s elf-selection bias, response bias, and 
unmeasured confounding variables such as workplace culture and 
managerial support could influence the outcomes.  
Copilot Usage in the Workplace Survey (Alexia Cambon , Alex 
Farach, Margarita Bermejo -Cano, and Eric Knudsen ) 
More study findings available in AI Data Drop: The 11 by 11 
Tipping Point  
While the Work Trend Index survey described above focused on 
generative AI in general , researchers also conducted  a broad survey 
focused specifically on Copilot for Microsoft 365, asking enterprise 
Copilot users  about their  perceived benefits, time savings, and 
overall job satisfaction.  This 20-minute, anonymous survey , which 
is ongoing, is being distributed to people with Copilot licenses at 
participating customer organizations from October 1, 2023, to 
November 1, 2024. Analysis here is based on 885 responses 
collected up to February 1, 2024 , from people  who had used 
Copilot for more than three weeks  at the time of survey response . 
  
The survey results suggest that people who use d Copilot for an 
extended period receive significant benefits from doing so. 
Researchers analyzed three distinct categories of usage durations: 
3-6 weeks, 7 -10 weeks, and more than 10 weeks. The analysis 
employed a 5 -point Likert scale, where 1 represents " Strongly 
Disagree" and 5 represents "Strongly Agree."  
 
Respondents who had been using Copilot for more than 10 weeks 
reported greater benefits compared to those with shorter usage 
durations. For example, for the question "Using Copilot in Teams 
allows me to attend fewer meetings," those using Copilot for 3 -6

reported greater benefits compared to those with shorter usage 
durations. For example, for the question "Using Copilot in Teams 
allows me to attend fewer meetings," those using Copilot for 3 -6  
Figure 2. Variable importance in predicting AI power usage  
Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
5 
 weeks had an average response of 2.66 ( variance 0.81) and those 
with more than 10 weeks of usage had an average of 3.06 ( variance 
1.34). For the question “Using Copilot helps me to enjoy my work 
more” the average for the 3 -6 week group was 3.4 and for the over 
10-weeks group it was 3.6.  All results reported in this analysis are 
statistically significant, as confirmed by ANOVA tests (p < 0.05).  
 
It is essential to acknowledge the limitations of this self-reported 
data. While  researchers  found significant associations, establishing 
causation is challenging. People who are more inclined to use 
productivity tools like Copilot may also be those who naturally 
experience higher job satisfaction, creating potential self -selection 
bias. Additionally, unmeasured factors such as managerial support 
or workplace culture could  influence both Copilot usage and job 
satisfaction.  This study also relied  on self-reported data that 
introduces the possibility of response bias.  
Study on Generative Search Engines and Task Complexity  
(Siddharth Suri, Scott Counts, Leijie Wang, Chacha Chen, 
Mengting Wan, Tara Safavi, Jennifer Neville, Chirag Shah, Ryen 
W. White, Reid Andersen, Georg Buscher, Sathish Manivannan, 
Nagu Rangan, and Longqi Yang ) 
More study details available in The Use of Generative Search 
Engines for Knowledge Work and Complex Tasks  (Suri et al. 2024) 
Search is a  common task in real-world workflows . To understand 
how the use of AI-augmented search differs from traditional search, 
researchers analyzed 80 ,000 randomly selected, de -identified 
conversations from the consumer version of Copilot in Bing and 
traditional Bing searches . They used GPT -4 to classify each 
conversation and search by topic domain. They found that  chats 
with Bing Copilot tend to focus on

entities.description: Data collected from individuals reporting their own experiences and perceptions, which may introduce response bias
